ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  I interacted with both equally
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Michaela Foster
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy (I wasn't able to go to Michaela's section with my schedule)
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Judy, Chelsea
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Both teaching assistants were very helpful and available but I suppose I worked more with Chelsea
Instructor: Michaela Olivia Foster  I interacted with both equally
Instructor: Michaela Olivia Foster  Michaela
Instructor: Michaela Olivia Foster  Michaela Foster
Instructor: Michaela Olivia Foster  Michaela
Instructor: Michaela Olivia Foster  Michaela was very helpful in explaining the material and was available to help the students.
Instructor: Michaela Olivia Foster  Foster Michaela

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  PhD students with vast knowledge and experience
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Very organized, responded promptly, great at explaining confusing material to the class during discussion groups.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea did a great job of leading section. She was able to answer questions and walk us through the material.

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea was great, she help clarify some of Ben's confusing statements and was really helpful with the paper. The only thing, that is more of an organizational thing is to better schedule the sessions so there were even in terms of students.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  I would have liked more feedback on my midterm and final paper sections.

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea was always available, happy to help, and prompt in her response to questions. I appreciated her putting together a PP deck to have as part of section. I think Chelsea could have done a better job of setting a firm and structured tone for section. There were many weeks when section felt too unstructured and casual to me, and therefore not particularly productive. I also think Chelsea could improve in leading interesting provocative conversations. Sometimes I felt like she would automatically agree with participants' comments too often. I think there were instances in which she could have played devil's advocate a bit more and pushed students to defend their logic or explain themselves more.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Very organized, thorough and a great discussion leader.

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea was very available to help and meet with students. She was very patient with students and helpful. Sometimes it seemed that she struggled to provide examples to help clarify questions.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea was helpful and responsive to questions.
Instructor: Michaela Olivia Foster  PhD students with vast knowledge and experience
Instructor: Michaela Olivia Foster  Very organized, responded promptly, great at explaining confusing material to the class during discussion groups.
Instructor: Michaela Olivia Foster  Michaela was helpful in explaining material but in presenting she tended to just read the bullet points off of the slides instead of adding any of her own input.
Instructor: Michaela Olivia Foster  Michaela is very nice and she is good at her work. And she is very friendly to international students.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: N/A

Professor Cashore has a lot of important things to teach however this course was unorganized and repetitive. The lectures were often quite similar, especially some of the anecdotes which we heard repeatedly over the course of the semester. The readings assigned for the course and the lectures were not complimentary to one another. Often, the lecture simply summarized the readings. Assuming we had done the readings, hearing the lecture did not add much to our learning.

This class had a lot of potential, but I feel it was never reached. Ben Cashore has so much knowledge to share, but the class was so disorganized that much of it was lost. For example, we were always rushed to finish the material at the end of the class, so we often did not get to learn about how the theoretical concepts discussed could be applied to environmental topics. I feel like I would have gained much more from the class if we had spent more time applying the theories learned

I enjoyed the class and the professor but I did think it was odd that he didn't know our names and didn't review our work (to my knowledge) except for our final papers. He also had to miss a few classes for conferences, or hold shortened make up classes, which is not ideal when we are paying so much money for school.
I loved the multi-goal policy analysis, but I would have liked to have reviewed some professional samples (non-student work).
Question 15: I found the course very beneficial and the subject matter extremely relevant.

Professor Cashore is clearly committed to supporting the education of his students. I really appreciated that whenever there was a question he would work with the student to make sure they truly understood the material.
I will answer in following boxes.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The course was all about what one needs to be ready for the world outside of school
Some of the topics we covered (ex. theories of power) were very useful and definitely have impacted my thinking.

There are many important lessons in this course about problem definitions, types of power, questioning our assumptions. All of these topics are, I believe, core to what students at FES should be learning. Creating the policy analysis was a highlight -- it is an interesting assignment and enjoyable that we can make it our own.
Discussion Section
It is a good into to the world of policy- I learned very much about the policy process and how new policies can be created.

Learning how to write a policy memo was very useful. I also appreciated that we had the chance to write each section of the memo separately and receive feedback. The book for the course was also very useful.
I think that the lessons were very useful and you might find yourself thinking in those terms for a long time (Power everywhere)
The final paper.

My favorite component of this course was writing the policy analysis. I think this exercise was extremely helpful in solidifying and applying all that we learned throughout the semester. I also appreciated the way in which work on this project was broken up throughout the semester, and explained along the way. I also thought the structure of the course was helpful. I appreciated beginning with theory and moving into practice throughout the course. Our early readings about power and different governance models were extremely helpful in shaping my understanding of content later on.
Having the chance of writing a real policy memo.

The course structure was very clear, the lectures were engaging and I enjoyed the assigned reading. I also loved working on the policy analysis, learned a lot and appreciated the way it was broken up.

The aspect of the course that I enjoyed most was the multi-goal analysis paper. This was an opportunity for us to compile everything we learned from the semester into a research paper exploring various policies. The other beneficial aspects were the breakout groups during class in which we would discuss course topics in small groups. This helped transform conceptual ideas into real world topics. The only problem is we rarely had time to hear the results of the breakout groups since the class would run out of time for the groups to present. I really appreciated Professor Cashore's personal examples from his own experience. He did a good job of integrating examples into the material.
professor Ben will not judge the policies but open your minds to help you think how to evaluate or analyze policies.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: N/A

The professor clearly did not make this class a priority. He was consistently late, often underprepared with outdated presentations, missed 3 classes (made up 1.5), didn't know deadlines or assignment expectations, and didn't learn students' names. His commitment to student learning was very disappointing.

This class really focused on only one aspect of policy building. The professor only assigned readings that aligned with his views and the readings on topics he disagreed with turned out to be negative reviews of these systems. Classes focussed on the readings and just overviews of other peoples work without a true understanding of why we should use one specific method. The readings were convoluted and used complicated language for no reason what so ever creating very frustrating and long reading assignments.
The prof. needs to do a better job of managing the class. We went off on tangents too many times which distracted from the material we were supposed to learn.
The readings and the lectures should be complimentary to each other, not repetitive. The answers to the tests should not be given to us during the discussion sections ahead of time.
Second half of the course

Organization. The content of the class is great, but we rarely got to all of it because we would run out of time, or class was cancelled and rescheduled at an inconvenient time. More application of the theories to environmental issues would be great as well, especially at the end of the class. Learning how feasibility, policy learning, etc could be altered by us in order to influence policy choices would have been a nice conclusion. I feel like everything was left up in the air.

Class lectures were often rushed or went over time. A big part of this was due student questions and comments. There needs to be a better balance. When we rushed through the material I didn't get anything out of it. There is also a tendancy to use the same examples repeatedly. My understanding of a theory or idea would be deeper with a greater variety of examples.
Lecture structure -- most were a review of the readings.

My biggest feedback about this course is that the class sessions felt both rushed and plodding. I think some more thought could be put into the pacing in order to avoid these feelings. There were classes during which I felt like we moved slowly (I would argue too slowly) through one bit of material, which led to rushing through what remained at the end. I also think there was a little bit too much repeating of content from readings during class. I would have liked the class time to be spent building on the readings more than summarizing them.

I didn't find the space of the classroom very conducive to discussion. While sitting in a circle is helpful in small groups, in a larger group I found it overwhelming. I think facing forward might have actually provoked more responses from different members of the class. I also thought that break-out sessions would have been more beneficial if the asks were a little more specific. When asked to develop a policy basket during break-out sessions, my groups always came to the same conclusion--we just don't have enough information in such a short time frame.

Overall, this is an good course with important material on policy and politics, but the execution is hampered by poor organization. Professor Cashore struggled with time management. He seldom finished the power points he prepared, and oftentimes we would be unable to finish group exercises due to time limitations. The class would either go over or run out of time. The disorganization was also made apparent by the lack of communication and clarity between the TAs and the Professor. Whether it was regarding time, due dates or assignments, the TAs and the Professor either had different answers, were unaware of what the other had stated, or used class time to clarify. Professor Cashore relied on the same examples to elucidate the material, throughout the whole semester and would benefit from integrating new examples. The class could be improved if the TAs and Professor met outside of class to get organized and if Professor Cashore established an agenda with time allotments for each topic to ensure that he covers all the relative material.
I think that there were too many in-class exercises that didn't really contribute very much to learning.
It will be good if professor Ben can add more examples his explanations of concepts or ideologies.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes
Effective
The discussion sessions were extremely helpful for clarifying material and having a chance to ask questions.
The lab time was useful. It gave me a chance to ask more questions or review material. It also gave us the chance to do some role playing to think through how things are acted out in the real world.

Overall this relationships was effective. However, there were a few sections that I found to be repetitive of the class. I also think that some of the work on our policy analyses in section was a little overwrought -- for instance, it felt like we talked about problem definitions during too many meetings.
Yes, it was great to have space to clarify and discuss class concepts further in a smaller group.
They were mostly complimentary. The discussion sections were most helpful in preparing for the quizzes and midterm and in helping us with our final paper.
I like the discussion sections.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Policy analysis is crucial and that this course covered all its aspects was trulls helpful
I took this course as an intro into the policy world, to gain an understanding of how it works. I most likely won't take many more policy courses.

This course gave me an overarching conceptual understanding of governance processes, the role of power in shaping all parts of this process, and an applied idea of how I would approach developing policy. I believe this knowledge will prove invaluable throughout my career. This course has taught me to question cultural norms and existing systems in new and important ways, and to think in new ways about how to catalyze change. I'm very glad I took this course.
This course actually inspired me to consider policy research in my future career.
Political analysis is critical to address many environmental problems. The tools learned in this class are useful to carry on this analysis.

This is a good class if you have rich experiences in this field. For a starter, I am confused about some concepts and did not get a clear picture of this class. However, this is my own problem not from the faculty side. And the last class of this course was very inspiring and I like it.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I need the expertise and knowledge needed to be a good policy analyst
It's a foundation class.
Science influences policy and visa versa. I had a strong science background but not enough policy and I wanted to change that.
I wanted to refresh my knowledge of the policymaking process.
To gain a better understanding of how policy is developed and executed, specifically in the environmental arena.
I had no previous background in policy analysis and wanted to, at the very least, understand the basics.
In order to gain a better understand of the policy-making process.
I am interested in energy policy and needed a good policy foundation.
I would like to have a general picture of policy analyzing.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, very much so
I was really looking forward to this course because it is incredibly relevant to my hopeful career path and was thoroughly disappointed to find that I don't feel like I gained much from this course.
No
I definitely gained an intro to policy, which is what I expected, but I did not come away with as much knowledge of how to influence the policy process as I had hoped.

Yes, but I would have liked to spend more time on the last few lectures. I feel like that was the crux of the class and what we should really use in our work going forward, and we had to rush through it.
Yes!

I loved writing the multi-goal policy analysis. I wish we would have studied how to write one a little more. I would have loved to have reviewed and critiqued professional exemplars in class or discussion.
Yes absolutely, and the opportunity to work on the policy analysis was an added bonus.
Yes, it greatly demystified the policy making process.
It did.
Mostly.
Yes to a certain extent, but the course was much more theoretical than I had anticipated.
Not very much but this absolutely open my minds in this part.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: gained insights into new perspectives from the various background in the group and how they understood the world

I did not find the group work in discussion section all that valuable. Because we were working off of scenarios where most of us had very little understanding/context, it was challenging to put to use many of the skills we learned. I think more valuable would be to have one or two case studies that we learn about in the beginning, fully understand the context, and then utilize those throughout the course.

Working on case studies in class was sometimes helpful, but I struggled often because I did not have as much knowledge of the problem as I needed to completely do the assignment. I think group time would have been used much more effectively if we discussed problems that were well known, or if we were briefed on them beforehand. Or possibly, we could be assigned to groups at the beginning of the semester, and worked on one case study throughout the course instead of learning a new one each time.
It was interesting to get to see the different ideas that people might have about the same topics.

Group work was limited and we often drew the same conclusions because we did not have enough background knowledge of the issues discussed to develop substantial, realistic solutions. Therefore if any one person in the class had greater knowledge about the subject matter at hand, they often dominated conversations. I think having a mix of concepts/problems to discuss (e.g., more urban examples) would have resolved this issue.
We were broken up into groups nearly every class for a breakout session to discuss a topic relative to the material. I found this to be very helpful in deepening my understanding of the topics.
NA

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it. You'll definitely need it

If you're looking for a general understanding of political science/policy decision-making, I would not take this class. You can find that learning in a different, better organized, more engaging class.

Ben is a great professor, but you should know that he will not give you a direct answer all the time, instead he will make you think so you will come with an answer on your own. That thing might be frustrating to some people, especially if you want to learn very practical tools and not ponder about the underlying themes of political science. Nevertheless, at least for me it was worth it, I can see myself using many of the concepts for a long time. Also, be prepare to read and if you have never taken a political science class, give it a shot, many topics are very interesting an can help you even if you are not even planning to actively work in policy making.
I have a background in Political Science and I still found the course to be beneficial to my academic and professional development.

I would advise students to be patient with this course, and trust that Professor Cashore knows what he's doing (and that the course will come full circle by the end). I would also recommend putting in the effort to do the components of the policy analysis well so that it's less of a giant task at the end.
The multi-goal policy analysis is very fun, but give it enough time and pace yourself.

Professor Cashore is incredibly knowledgable, and you can gain a lot through the class assignments. If you have taken policy classes before, this might not be as beneficial for you. The lectures and readings are very repetitive, and Professor Cashore will explain the takeaways from the readings in his lecture.
It will be better if you can take class with relatively rich working experience.
